terms.term: Describe the divisions of the NS (6m)
terms.definition: The human nervous system is divided into two broad sections, the central nervous system (CNS) which contains the brain and spinal cord and is responsible for controlling behaviour and regulating the body's physiological processes through collecting information from sensory receptors and sending messages to effectors, eg. Muscles and glands, and the peripheral nervous system (PNS) which consists of all the nerves outside of the CNS and is responsible for relaying nerve impulses form the CNS to rest of the body and vice versa, via neurons; It also sends information from the outside world to the CNS to be processed. The PNS is then sub-divided into the Autonomic nervous system (ANS) which controls vital involuntary actions such as heartbeat and digestion and the somatic nervous system (SNS) which regulates voluntary actions such as skeletal muscle movement. The ANS is finally split up into the sympathetic NS which is responsible for the “fight or flight” response and parasympathetic NS which is responsible for the “rest and digest” response.
Specialised network of cells in the human body and the primary internal communication system.

To collect, process and respond to info in environment 
To coordinate workings of different organs and cells in body
Peripheral and central
All nerves outside of central (nerves stretch from spinal cord to extremities)
Relays nerve impulses between cns and body (+outside world to CNS), subdivided into ans and sns which regulate voluntary and involuntary processes.
Regulates involuntary vital actions eg heart beat, breathing, digestion. Stress response (symp / parasympathetic). Regulates homeostasis.

Regulates voluntary processes (muscle movement)
Via motor pathways, carries sensory info from outside world to brain and provides effector response
Receives info from sensory receptors

Sensory receptors (carry info to brain and spinal cord)
Motor pathways (allows brain to control movement)
Sympathetic / parasympathetic

Fight or flight 
Enables us to deal with stressors in the environment 
Impulse travels from sympathetic NS to organs to prepare for action when faced with dangerous situations. Eg. HR BR BP all increase whilst suppressing less important processes for the situation like digestion.

Rest and digest 
-relaxes body and return it to normal resting state after stressor has passed/been dealt with.
-slows down HR BP BR, any previously slowed down functions eg. Digestion restarted.
Brain / spinal cord

Controls behvaiour 
Regulates body’s physiological processes by collecting info from sensory receptors and sending impulses to effectors.

Relays info between brain and body 
Connects pns and nerves 
Responsible for reflex actions

Wrinkly outer layer of Brian 
3mm thick 
Peaks and troughs = sulci and gyri (for more surface area and optimal functioning 
Only in mammals

Contains thalamus :
Relay station for nerve impulses from senses, routes them to appropriate part of brain to be processes. 
Contains hypothalamus: 
Responsible for homeostasis 
Links nervous and endocrine system
“Little brain” - controls balance and coordination

Connects brain and spinal cord 
Controls involuntary processes (consciousness, HR, Breathing)

Higher order functions eg. Planning, logic, abstract reasoning.
Contains motor cortex to bring about movement.

Integrates info from different senses
Plays important role in spatial navigation 
Contains somatosensory cortex

Processes auditory info
Auditory cortex

Visual cortex 
Processes visual info
Wave of electrochemical changes which travel along length of neuron
Specialised cells adapted to ensure efficient transmission of electrical impulses unidirectionally across the body’s systems

terms.term: Label the parts of a neuron
terms.definition: Dendrites, soma, axon, axon terminal

terms.term: Outline structure and function of a neuron
terms.definition:
Long - able to transport electrical impulses quickly / efficiently, requiring minimal neurons to get from sens organ to spinal cord
Myelin sheath - insulates axon allowing for faster transmission of electrical impulses
Dendrites- many branches containing lots of receptors allow for large surface area for more connections (faster transmission)
Soma contains nucleus and other organelles, provides energy for function

terms.term: Compare differences between 3 types of neurons (structural)
terms.definition: Sensory has soma in axon whilst relay and motor have it at one end. Relay has a short axon whilst sensory and motor are longer. Sensory is attached to receptor cell whilst motor is attached to effector and relay is within spinal cord.

terms.term: Compare functional differences between relay motor sensory
terms.definition:
Sensory transmits electrical impulses from sense organ to CNS (receives info)
Relay is within spinal cord used during reflex arcs between sensory and motor (processes info)
Motor transmits impulse from CNS to effector to bring about a response

terms.term: Describe s and f of a neuron
terms.definition:
Neurons enable communication within the NS
Soma contains nucleus and genetic material, as well as other organelles which provide the cell with energy to transmit electrical impulses at a fast rate.
Branch like dendrites extend from cell body and have many receptors allowing for faster transmission rate of synaptic transmission
Axon carries message away from soma and has myelin sheath (insulator) to increase speed of transmission
Axon terminal contain neurotransmitters in vesicles which diffuse during synaptic transmission

terms.term: Describe the structure and process of synaptic transmission (6)
terms.definition:
Action potential travels down axon unidirectionally and reaches pre-synaptic membrane.
Vesicles move towards axon terminal and release neurotransmitters into synaptic gap (electrical - chemical)
Neurotransmitters diffuse across gap 
Bind with receptors on postsynaptic neuron (back to electrical)
Neurotransmitters are excitory (noradrenaline/dopamine) or inhibitory(serotonin/GABA) decided by summation
After this reuptake may occur where neurotransmitters are taken back into vesicles to be reused or they are broken down by enzymes.

Serotonin 
GABA

Noradrenaline
Dopamine
Acetylcholine
Increase the likelihood of an impulse being transferred to the postsynaptic neuron. Results in an excitatory postsynaptic potential which means it is more likely to be reuptaken.
Decrease likelihood of presynaptic neuron firing as binding results in inhibitory postsynaptic potential.
Determines whether or not cell fires by calculating the sum of excitatory and inhibitory post synaptic potentials

terms.term: What is the endocrine system made of?
terms.definition: Glands and hormones

Metabolism 
Growth 
Fight / flight 
Rest / digest

Adrenal medulla 
Adrenal cortex

Produces cortisol, released due to chronic stress
Maintains blood glucose, suppresses immune system, low sensitivity to pain

Releases nor/adrenaline, due to acute stress preparing body for fight/flight 
Increased BR,HR,RR
Dilated pupils 
Suppresses digestive system and salivation

Controlled by hypothalamus
Releases hormones which control other glands
Anterior pituitary (releases ACTH) as part of HPA axis response to chronic stress. Produces LH and FSH as part of menstrual cycle.
Posterior pituitary (release oxytocin). Stimulates contraction of uterus in childbirth - involved in mother-infant bonding. Reduces anxiety and involved in sexual behaviour in males. 
In charge of growth hormones

Body’s automatic phsyiological reaction to perceived stressors. Prepares body to fight/flee to maximise survival. Works as part of ANS (Symp. Branch) alongside endocrine system. Rapidly mobilises energy stores and focuses body’s resources on immediate action.

terms.term: Outline the role of the hypothalamus
terms.definition:
Controls pituitary gland
Stimulates it, triggering ANS (symp. Branch) for fight/flight response. 
Links NS and endocrine system
Detects stressor after notified by amygdala 
Triggers SAM pathway (acute stress)
HPA axis for chronic stress
Maintains homeostasis 
Calls for hormone release via pituitary gland, controlling other glands.

terms.term: How is the Symp. NS activated and its role
terms.definition: Amygdala notifies hypothalamus which detects stressor and activates pituitary gland. this activates sympNS which changes body to sympathetic state. SympNS sends signals via neurons to adrenal gland releasing nor/adrenline into bloodstream which prepares body for rapid action by increasing alertness.

Used during acute stress
Hypothalamus detects stressor and activates sympathetic NS 
Adrenal medulla stimulated to release adrenaline 
Hormones circulate in bloodstream causing physiological changes such as increased BR,HR,RR Dilated pupils and suppressed digestion/salivation

Used in chronic stress
Hypothalamus detects stressor and releases CRH 
This stimulates pituitary gland to secrete ACTH 
ACTH stimulates adrenal cortex to produce cortisol 
Cortisol maintains blood glucose,suppresses immune system, lowers sensitivity to pain to help body. Pie with prolonged stress.

terms.term: Outline role of parasympathetic NS and process of rest and digest
terms.definition:
Returns body to resting state after stressor dealt eight. 
Rest and digest/homeostasis restoration counteracts effects of sympathetic NS.
Slows HRBRRR
Stimulates digestion 
Constriction of pupils 
Overall relaxation of body

terms.term: How does fight/flight differ in short term vs long terms stress situations
terms.definition:
Acute involves SAM chronic involves HPA axis. Hormones in acute = nor/adrenaline chronic = cortisol 
Acute=immediate physical arousal, doesn’t last long. Chronic = sustained energy, immune suppression, health impacts if too prolonged like heart disease.

terms.term: Why might fight or flight response not be useful during a driving test
terms.definition:
Adrenaline released causing increase HR and BR, could be off putting and unhelpful eg. Sweaty hands may be harder to hold wheel. 
Allows for a quick reaction to fight or run away from stressor but neither of these options would be helpful as if you ran away or attacked the instructor you would fail the test.
Can cause health issues if prolonged like heart disease, so it’s unhelpful as would cause unhealthiness

Outdated - not useful for modern day stressors, leads to health  issues 
Taylor et al’s contradicting evidence - andocentric bias- women have different stress response “tend and befriend” - beta bias - not fully comprehensive 
Grays “freeze” theory - rapid C-B analysis, not considered 
+provides starting point
